senses.de: To roughly calculate or judge the value, number, quantity, or extent of something.
senses.ex: I estimate that I'll be there in an hour.

Tips.title: Rough Calculation
Tips.description: Emphasizes a non-exact or approximate figure, not precise.
Tips.example: Can you estimate how many people attended the concert?

Tips.title: Quick Judgement
Tips.description: Often used when there's limited information, to make a quick judgment.
Tips.example: We'll need to estimate how much paint to buy without measuring the room.

senses.de: A rough calculation or judgment of the value, number, quantity, or extent of something.
senses.ex: The estimate for the project was too high for us to afford.

Tips.title: Cost Context
Tips.description: Commonly used in business or finance to discuss the probable cost.
Tips.example: The estimate for the new building's construction seems reasonable.

Tips.title: Before Formal Quote
Tips.description: An estimate is usually given before a detailed analysis for a formal quote.
Tips.example: Could you give me an estimate before we proceed to the detailed quotation?

senses.de: To form an opinion or judgment about.
senses.ex: He estimated her to be in her early thirties.

Tips.title: Opinion Based
Tips.description: Reflects a personal belief or opinion rather than an exact measurement.
Tips.example: She estimated that the job would take five days to complete.

Tips.title: Judging Qualities
Tips.description: Involves judging someone or something's qualities without precise tools.
Tips.example: He estimated the weight of the fish to be around 10 pounds.

senses.de: A statement of the approximate cost of work to be done, such as a building project or car repairs.
senses.ex: The contractor gave us an estimate for the repairs.

Tips.title: Approximate Cost
Tips.description: An estimated cost which is subject to change on a project's final assessment.
Tips.example: The architect's estimate for the renovation was slightly over our budget.

Tips.title: Starting Point
Tips.description: Initial figure or cost that can help start planning or decision making.
Tips.example: Their repair estimate allowed us to decide whether to fix the car or buy a new one.

senses.de: To calculate approximately (the amount, extent, magnitude, position, or value of something).
senses.ex: We need to estimate the population mean.

Tips.title: Inexact Science
Tips.description: In fields like statistics, it's understood that estimates have a margin of error.
Tips.example: The researchers estimated the growth rate to be between 2% and 4%.

Tips.title: Assumption-Based
Tips.description: Relies on assumptions due to a lack of complete data or information.
Tips.example: To estimate our chances, we assumed the competitor's sales numbers were accurate.

Approximate.wordDefinition:
Approximate and estimate both refer to making a guess, but there is a slight difference in their usage.

Approximate means close to the exact amount or size, and is often used when the exact number is unknown or difficult to determine.

For example, "The length of the river is approximately 50 kilometers."

Approximate refers to a close guess of an exact amount, while estimate is more of a calculated guess based on information available.

Assess.wordDefinition: Assess means to evaluate something's quality or nature, based on specific criteria. It's like grading an essay or judging an athlete's performance.

Calculate.wordDefinition:
Calculate refers to finding the exact answer or solution using known formulas and data. It involves precise mathematical procedures and yields an answer that is as accurate as possible.

You would use calculate when you need the exact solution to a problem, such as finding the area of a circle, or the speed of a moving object.

Evaluate.wordDefinition:
Evaluate means to assess or analyze something, often in order to make a judgment or decision. For example, if you evaluate a job offer, you might consider the salary, benefits, and other aspects of the job in order to decide if it's the right fit for you.

In general, estimates are useful when you don't have all the information you need to make a precise calculation or decision, while evaluations are useful when you need to assess the value or quality of something in order to make a decision.

Guess.wordDefinition:
It involves using some logic and reasoning to come up with an educated guess.

Guess means to make a prediction or conjecture about something with little or no information or basis, often relying on chance or intuition rather than evidence.

For example, if you were asked to estimate the number of people attending a party, you would look at how many chairs, tables or food and drinks have been prepared, and make a calculated guess based on that information.

However, if you were asked to guess how many candies are in a jar without any clues, you would have to rely on your own intuition and make a random guess without any logic.

An estimate is more reliable and accurate than a guess since it is based on some evidence or reasoning whereas a guess is simply a shot in the dark.

Judgement.wordDefinition:
A judgement is an opinion or decision formed through analysis and evaluation of a situation or facts. It involves weighing various factors and choosing between alternatives.

For example, if you are asked to make a judgement about the performance of a student you may consider their grades, attendance, behavior and other relevant information to determine whether they have met the required standards.

An estimate is a calculation of an unknown value based on known factors, while a judgement is a decision or opinion formed through analysis and evaluation.

Opinion.wordDefinition:
Opinion is used to express a personal belief or judgement about something. For example, when someone says they like a particular type of music, that is their opinion.

The main difference between estimate and opinion is that an estimate is based on available information and aimed at predicting a likely outcome, while an opinion is a personal belief or judgement.

Prediction.wordDefinition:
An estimate is an educated guess based on information available at the time, while a prediction is a statement about what might happen in the future.

If you were making a prediction about the weather, you might look at current weather patterns and make an informed guess about what the weather will be like tomorrow or next week.

Predictions are used when you want to make a statement about what is likely to happen in the future based on current information.

Projection.wordDefinition:
A projection is a more formal calculation that attempts to predict what something will be like in the future based on current trends or patterns.

Projections are made with the help of more data and an understanding of how things are likely to change. For example, if someone is projecting the demand for a particular product over the next five years, they would use data on how demand has changed in the past, as well as data on current market conditions and trends.

Overall, estimates are more informal and based on limited information, while projections are more formal and use more data to make predictions about the future.
